	In June 2019, Mammoth Complex performed a seismic assessment of piping and equipment for the existing G1, G2 and G3 plants. Since CD4 is newly constructed, a seismic assessment will be conducted after construction is completed in the next seismic assessment for the Mammoth Complex. 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Mammoth Complex conducted PHA studies to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the PHA reports for G1/G3, G2, and CD4. All recommendations for G1 and G3 are closed. At G2, two MOC driven recommendations are pending completion or evaluation. At CD4, one recommendation is still pending completion. This recommendation is around a US Forest Service shooting area nearby, Ormat has submitted plans for remediation and awaiting response from US Forest Service to move forward if possible.  
In addition to the implementation of PHA recommendations, in conjunction with ongoing discussions with the CUPA and other planning efforts, Mammoth Complex has implemented, or is planning to implement, several additional process and program improvements to further improve facility safety and operability. Per these discussions and efforts, Mammoth Complex is implementing programs to:
	Improve preventative maintenance and inspection tasks to ensure Recognized And Generally Acceptable Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) are addressed,
	Implement a new software package (SAP) to enable better maintenance tracking and documentation,
	Revise the Compliance Auditing program to require the use of independent auditors from other Ormat locations,
	Improve tracking and completion of Compliance Audit and PHA Recommendations with the implementation of new tracking tools, and 
	Improve the document control system.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
One accident occurred at the Mammoth Complex stationary source meeting the criteria that requires reporting under the CalARP and EPA RMP programs. This was the CD4 Level 2/3 condenser collector level transmitter leak that occurred from 12/13/22 to 12/16/2022 that released an estimated 24,938 lbs of n-butane. It was found that a local gauge had froze and broke, this was removed from service and replaced with a plug on 12/16/22.  
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
Mammoth Complex staff are not First Responders. Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency. Mammoth Complex coordinates with the local fire department through activities such as conducting plant tours, inviting fire fighters to annual emergency response drills, providing current emergency response documents, and supporting responders with annual donations.  Site visits have been coordinated the last several years. An emergency action plan is in place that meets the requirements of CalARP, EPA RMP, OSHA PSM, and CalOSHA PSM.

EXTERNAL EVENTS ANALYSIS INFORMATION
Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, 2745.7(q); the following external events analysis information were reviewed and are submitted with the CalARP documentation: 
	The types of natural and human caused external events considered in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) Section 2760.2. 
o	During the PHAs, the PHA team considered a broad list of external events. The PHA addressed general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of motive fluid. The External Events that were considered are detailed within the PHA worksheets, wh

This document is included in the RMP submittal and is also attached as a file to the EPA RMP eSubmit document.
RISK CONSIDERATIONS
Although the use of the motive fluids has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach public receptors, Mammoth Pacific has worked to minimize these potential risks and structured its process design and safety programs to make the worst-case type of event improbable.  
Design safeguards include the following: 
	Automatic Shutdown is initiated when select process variable ranges are exceeded.
o	Stop brine flow, initiating unit depressurization
o	Process isolation valves, removing motive fluid feed to turbines to stop turbine rotation
o	Stop process feed pumps
o	Disconnect electrical grid breakers 
	Operator-initiated Shutdown can be activated from the control room and from various locations around the stationary source to prompt the same actions initiated by an automatic shutdown. 
	Pressure Relief System is designed to prevent system overpressure due to process upsets such as blocked flow or accidents resulting in equipment exposure to fire.
	Deluge Systems 
	Physical Separation of Processes from all but a few potential public receptors.
Safety programs are defined by the Accidental Release Prevention Program described below.
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
As part of the implementation of the accidental release prevention programs, program elements are documented and implemented by Mammoth Complex to manage process safety issues associated with the use of the motive fluids. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently followed to ensure safe practices are being performed.
The facilitys `maximum intended inventory of the motive fluids is over the 10,000 pound regulatory threshold quantity in each process. As a result, each of the covered processes is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3, Cal/OSHA PSM and Federal OSHA PSM.

P and CalARP documentation to reflect the revised system. This submittal covers the changes made within the triggering timeframe. 
The CD4 process utilizes normal butane and isopentane as motive fluids. With the construction of the CD4 process, Mammoth Complex updated the Federal RMP and CalARP documents in anticipation of  the 2022 process commissioning. The regulated substances managed at the stationary source are the previously mentioned motive fluids, isobutane, normal butane and isopentane. The motive fluid circulates in a closed-loop power cycle, traveling through accumulators, pumps, heat exchangers, turbines, and condensers to produce electricity with turbine-driven generators. The electricity generated by this process is then sold to contracted off-takers. 
The maximum intended inventory is for the Mammoth Complex is a revised 686,042 pounds of isobutane, a revised 732,213 pounds of normal butane, and a revised 344,071 pounds of isopentane.  These revisions were required for increased volumes with the G2 repower and new assumptions within the calculations for CD4 and G1 after operational optimization and maintenance activities. A summary of the inventories can be found within the CalARP submittal. 
The site is currently operated by Mammoth Complex staff and is manned 24 hours a day. The facility employs approximately 24 personnel.
HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: One worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for each of the three geothermal power processes. The results are included with the CalARP submittal. 
Alternate Release Scenarios Results Summary
Scenario Description: An alternate release scenario was modeled for each of the three geothermal power processes. The results are included with the CalARP submittal.
Release Scenario Depiction
The worst case and alternate release scenario document include a pictorial depiction of the potential release impact zones.

ary source: G1, G2/G3, and CD4.  
G1 was built in 1984. In 2013, Mammoth Complex retrofitted the process with new, more efficient equipment and changed the motive fluid from isobutane to normal butane, which involved the installation of new equipment and controls. At that time Mammoth Complex completely replaced air-cooled condensers, replaced all turbines, turbine seals and lubrication systems with new equipment, installed 2 new heat exchangers and replaced 4 old ones, retubed 4 heat exchangers, replaced all PSVs, and installed new instrumentation and controls system. At the time of the G1 retrofit, Mammoth Complex updated the EPA RMP and CalARP documentation to reflect the revised system.  
The G2 and G3 plants were built in 1990. Given their relative proximity and interconnectivity they comprise a single process. Both G2 and G3 utilize isobutane as the motive fluid. In 2016, Mammoth Complex replaced the G2 air-cooled condensers with new units and in G3 replaced two of the six heat exchangers. In mid-2019, Mammoth Complex retrofitted the G3 plant with new, more efficient equipment. As part of this project, Mammoth Complex replaced all turbines, turbine seals and lubrication systems with new equipment, replaced all but two PSVs in the motive fluid and brine systems (Those two were replaced in 2022), installed new instrumentation and a new controls system, and replaced large piping segments involved in previous release incidents. At the time of the G3 retrofit, Mammoth Complex updated the EPA RMP and CalARP documentation to reflect the revised system. In October 2021, Mammoth Complex installed silencers installed on the G3 turbine bypass header to limit vibration during bypass operations.
In early 2023 Mammoth Complex retrofitted the G2 plant with new more efficient equipment. Including turbines, lube and seal oil skids, PSVs, brine injection pumps, and a new controls system. With the changes the G2 PHA was completely redone, therefore triggering updating the EPA RM

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
The Mammoth Complex facility uses geothermal resources to generate carbon-free baseline power, consistent with and supporting Californias climate goals.  
Mammoth Complex has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan to address California Accidental Release Prevention Program requirements (CalARP - California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2735-2785), the EPA Risk Management Program (EPA RMP - 40CFR68), OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA PSM - 29CFR1910.119) and Cal/OSHA Process Safety Management (CalOSHA PSM - California Code of Regulations, Title 8, §5189). Mammoth Complex has and will continue to work in collaboration with the CUPA in the development and implementation of this risk management program, including further revisions as appropriate. 
Mammoth Complex has a long-standing and strong commitment to worker and public safety and the safety of the neighboring community. This commitment is demonstrated by, among other things, the resources invested in accident prevention, personnel training, multifaceted inspection programs, and the priority placed on safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the motive fluid systems. Mammoth Complex staff are highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using those motive fluids for geothermal power production.
STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
Mammoth Complexs geothermal power production facility is fueled by geothermal brine from the Casa Diablo Geothermal Reservoir. The facility is in Mammoth Lakes, California, approximately 5 miles east of the Town of Mammoth Lakes and 0.5 miles east of State Route 395.  The area around the facility is rugged and generally uninhabited. The facility uses the process motive fluids as working fluids in a binary Rankine cycle process for power production. There are a total of three processes in the station
